values.title: Discover Green Spaces and Wildlife in Berlin

sections.title: Discover Green Spaces and Wildlife in Berlin
sections.content:
Most people associate Berlin with the former DDR, the wall, a big city rebuilt after the war, a popular holiday destination... a city full of history. But the city is not just about history, culture and nightlife... open green spaces and their wildlife and nature abound in the city ... giving everyone the chance to enjoy nature up close and first hand. 

 

The extent of Berlin's green side might surprise you. An average of around 80 trees line each kilometer of the city's streets, giving the city over 438,000 street trees alone ... and that just the start of the green story.

sections.title: Open Spaces in Berlin
sections.content:
Over 2500 open green areas in Berlin come in all shapes and sizes -  some manicured, some managed with nature in mind, and others allowed to run wild, many since the war. From small to large parks, dozens of lakes, graveyards, 161 square kilometers of forest areas, extensive water ways, nature reserves and abandoned railway lines these open areas are cherished as a green lung by Berlin's inhabitants - both human and the wildlife kind.

 

(The map opposite was produced for the ESRI Urban Observatory Project 2015 by UOdocent and shows the open areas in Berlin including Signature Parks, Other Parks and Open Spaces).

sections.title: The Tour
sections.content:
This tour of green spaces and wildlife areas will introduce you to just a small selection of these spaces in and around Berlin that I have got to know and explore. It is by no means a complete inventory of all the open spaces in the city. 

 

The map opposite shows the location of some wildlife areas. You can explore these areas directly from within this map, by enlarging and navigating around the map, and clicking on the location pins to read more in the pop up window. To see full sized images in the pop up just click on the thumbnail image to enlarge it. 

 

The wildlife areas in Berlin shown on this map are presented in more detail in the sections that follow. Here the parks and wildlife areas are arranged in alphabetical order by the name of the park or nature area. As you move through the list of sites an enlarged map showing features of interest within the area are shown in the map window. 

 

Enjoy the tour !

sections.title: BÄKEPARK
sections.content: Located in Steglitz beside the Teltow canal, Bäkepark includes a number of wetland areas including a pond and stream, with marginal woodland areas and open meadows. Waterbirds and butterflies are commonly seen.

sections.title: BERLIN WALL MEMORIAL BERNAUERSTRASSE
sections.content: Located directly on the former border strip in Bernauer Strasse is a preserved piece of the Berlin Wall with border strip and watchtower. The facility shows how the border facilities were constructed and gives visitors a lasting impression of the construction, which once divided Berlin and Germany. On either side of the retained wall section is a new greener park development following the path of the former wall.

sections.title: BOTANIC GARDENS DAHLEM
sections.content: The garden is located in the Berlin borough of Steglitz-Zehlendorf and covers 43 hectares. The garden complex consists of several buildings and glass-houses, such as the Cactus Pavilion and the Pavilion Victoria. The garden's open-air areas are sorted by plant geographic origin. The garden's arboretum covers a large area with ponds and open grassy flower meadows.

sections.title: BRITZER GARTEN
sections.content: Britz gardens are one of the most attractive recreational areas in Berlin. The 90 hectare park a variety of visitor attractions. At the centre of the gardens the is a large lake complex with beaches, bays, bridges and semi-natural reedswamp areas surrounded by woodlands and meadows. There are cafés, a museum railway and wildlife educational centre.

sections.title: CECILIENHOF
sections.content: Cecilienhof is located in the northern part of the large Neuer Garten park, close to the shore of the Jungfernsee lake in Potsdam. Cecilienhof was the last palace built by the House of Hohenzollern that ruled until the end of World War I. It is famous for having been the location of the Potsdam Conference in 1945. Cecilienhof is part of Potsdam UNESCO world heritage site. An open park landscape with reedswamp along the edge of the lake are the main habitats at this site.

sections.title: ENGELBECKEN
sections.content: The Engelbecken in Kreuzberg is a large pond, the only remaining wet remnant of the former Luisenstadt Canal which linked the Landwehr Canal with the Spree River. This canal has since mostly been drained and converted to a public park which follows the route of the former canal.

sections.title: ERHOLUNGSPARK MARZAHN
sections.content: Erholungspark Marzahn is a public park in Marzahn open since 1987 and covering 21 hectares. The park includes a variety of themed gardens from around the world including a Chinese, Oriental, Italian, Balinese, Korean, and Japanese garden. The park also includes less developed areas with woodland, small ponds and grassland areas. The park will host the International Garden Exhibition (IGA) festival in 2017.

sections.title: GLEISDREIECK PARK
sections.content: Gleisdreieck Park covers 26 hectares and is one of Berlins newest park developments. This new green space is being created on the site between Anhalter Bahnhof and Yorkstrasse, close to Potsdamer Platz. The park offers plenty of amenity areas, woodland and scrub, ponds, dry scree habitats and an extensive path network.

sections.title: HEILIGER SEE
sections.content: Heiliger See (Holy Lake) is a lake within the city limits of Potsdam. Its picturesque location amidst the historic parks and palaces of Potsdam, with the Marmorpalais on its west shore and Cecilienhof near the north shore, the lake is a popular goal for visitors. Reedswamps and wet woodland occur around the lakeshore.

sections.title: HUMBOLDTHEIN VOLKSPARK
sections.content:
The historically listed green space bears the name of the great naturalist Alexander von Humboldt. The park, which covers 29 hectares, includes a large World War II anti-aircraft bunker, surrounded by semi natural woodland. In the winter, six different species of bat hibernate in the bunker rooms. The bunker is the third largest bat hibernation site in Berlin.

 

The northern wall of the "large" bunker as well as the wall of the "small" bunker are used for sport climbing by advanced climbers. A vineyard within the park produces 200 bottles of wine annually.

sections.title: LANDWEHR CANAL
sections.content: The Landwehr canal is a 10.7 km long canal and runs parallel to the Spree river in Berlin. It was built between 1845 and 1850. A large canal lock occurs on the canal near the Zoologischer Garten. The canal is an important habitat for waterbirds.

sections.title: MARIENFELDE FREIZEITPARK
sections.content: Formerly the Marienfelde park was a large municipal dump for Berlin city covering some 15 hectares. When closed the area was rehabilitated and is now managed as a nature park, with stands of woodland, large open wildflower meadows, and a number of ponds, lakes and wetland areas which are managed to protect a number of amphibian and reptile species as well as birds.

sections.title: MAUERPARK
sections.content: Mauerpark is a public linear park in Berlin's Prenzlauer Berg district. The name translates as "Wall Park", referring to its status as a former part of the Berlin Wall and its Death Strip. The park is located at the border of Prenzlauer Berg and Gesundbrunnen district of former West Berlin. The park is much used by local residents at weekends and host a flea market.

sections.title: PANKE RIVER IN WEDDING
sections.content: The Panke river flows through Wedding in Berlin. The river is bordered by woodlands and ornamental planting. If you venture on a trip along the 23 km long Pankeweg route, you can discover more about the northern part of Berlin.

sections.title: PFAUENINSEL
sections.content: The Pfaueninsel (Peacock Island) is an island covering 67 hectares, in the River Havel situated in Berlin-Wannsee. It is a nature reserve and part of the UNESCO world heritage site that includes the Potsdam palaces. It is mostly wooded with some open and formal garden areas, and includes wet grassland and marginal swamp areas. It can only be reached by a small ferry, and is a popular tourist destination.

sections.title: ROETEPFUHL SEE
sections.content: A small pond in an urban setting near the Britzer gardens. The small pond is surrounded by reedswamp and wet woodland vegetation.

sections.title: SCHLOSS BRITZ
sections.content: The Schloss Britz (Britz castle) is the former manor house of a country estate. Located near the village of Britz, in Berlin-Neukölln. The manorial park is well preserved with its mature trees and its 1890s system of trails. The site includes a pond and grassland areas managed for their spring flowers.

sections.title: SCHLOSS CHARLOTTENBURG
sections.content: Charlottenburg Palace is largest royal palace still standing in the capital, Charlottenburg was erected as the summer residence of Sophie Charlotte, the first queen of Prussia, who was also the namesake for the surrounding district. The famous palace gardens contain the mausoleum of Queen Louise, the Belvedere with its world-renowned collection of KPM porcelain. The grounds include a lake and associated waterways, mature woodland areas, formal flower gardens and lawn areas.

sections.title: SCHLOSSPARK SANSSOUCI
sections.content: In 1744 Frederick the Great created a terraced garden designed in Sanssouci Park. Many additional places, baroque and informal gardens were added to the park complex in later years. Today the park landscape extends over an area of 290 hectares and has some 70 km of walkways. It includes extensive woodland planting, open flower rich meadows and a number of ponds, as well as the formal flower gardens.

sections.title: SCHOENEBERGER SÜDGELÄNDE
sections.content: Over the past 50 years, nature has reclaimed the Südgelände on the site of the former railway yard at Berlin-Tempelhof. The woodland and other habitats, covering 18 hectares, provide a home for a wealth of plants and animals. Some 50 species of bird and close to 100 species of bee occur in the park. The remnants of the historical railway line are still be seen in many of the woodland areas.

sections.title: SOPHIEN FRIEDHOF II
sections.content: Sophien Friedhof II is a graveyard located in Berlin Mitte. As is the case with many of the other urban graveyards in the city the graveyard is heavily wooded and a valuable habitat for songbirds and other wildlife.

sections.title: SPREE RIVER
STEGLITZ STADTPARK
sections.content: Stadtpark Steglitz is a busy park used by the residents of Steglitz. The park, covering 17 hectares, includes a number of ornamental ponds, with the main park being a mosaic of open lawn areas broken by woodland planting. There is a large children's playground in the park.

sections.title: TEMPELHOFER FELD
sections.content: Originally the Tempelhofer Feld was a military parade ground. At the beginning of the 1920s, Tempelhof airport was built on the 300 hectare site. After the airport closed in 2008, Berlin residents reclaimed the 386 hectare open space for public use following a referendum on its future use. Today the area has cycling, skating and jogging trail and picnic areas for all visitors.

sections.title: TIERGARTEN
sections.content: The Tiergarten is the former private hunting grounds of Great Elector Friedrich Wilhelm. The park has a diverse landscape including avenues, pathways, lawns, meadows, ponds, flower beds, landscaped gardens and extensive wilder woodland areas. Covering 210 hectares the "Großer Tiergarten" is the largest urban park of Berlin. It’s a favourite with locals and visitors, wonderful for a stroll, a breath of fresh air, a picnic, cycling or a jog or just lying out in the sun.

sections.title: TREPTOWER PARK
sections.content: Treptower Park is a park alongside the river Spree in Alt-Treptow, in the district of Treptow-Köpenick covering 88 hectares. Its prominent feature is the Soviet War Memorial, built to commemorate the 80,000 Soviet soldiers who fell in the Battle of Berlin in 1945. As a "public park" opened to all citizens in 1888, Treptow Park represented an innovation for its time. The park includes extensive woodland areas as well as a large pond, called the Karpfenteich.

sections.title: VIKTORIA LOUISE PARK
sections.content: Viktoria Louise Park is located in Schoeneberg. The park is highly managed with numerous flower beds, which are surrounded by a mature treeline. The park with its fountain is very popular with local residents.

sections.title: VIKTORIAPARK KREUZBERG
sections.content: The Viktoriapark (aka Victoriapark) is an urban park in Kreuzberg. It provides an excellent viewpoint over much of the central and southern portions of the city. The major landmark of the park is a monument erected in 1821 dedicated by King Frederick William III of Prussia to the Liberation Wars fought to free the German states from Napoleon. In summer an artificial waterfall originates at the foot of the monument and continues down the hillside to the intersection of Großbeerenstraße and Kreuzbergstraße.

sections.title: VOLKSPARK FRIEDRICHSHAIN
sections.content: Volkspark Friedrichshain is a large wooded urban park on the border of Friedrichshain and Prenzlauerberg which covers some 52 hectares. It is the oldest public park in Berlin. The park has several playgrounds, many large Liegewiesen (open areas for sunbathing), a pond, tennis courts, a wading pool, and a restaurant. It is also criss-crossed with walking paths.

sections.title: WUPATZSEE
sections.content:
Wupatzee is located on the eastern edge of Berlin just over the border into Brandenburg.  The site occurs in the Löcknitztal (Löcknitz valley) over half of which is  managed as a nature reserve.

 

The lake is surrounded by a narrow zone of reedswamp and wet deciduous swamp woodland, with conifer woodland beyond that. Wupatzee has a diverse wildlife.

sections.title: SMALL OPEN AREAS
sections.content: There are many small green areas, verges, yards and brownfield sites throughout the city which add a diversity of habitats for pioneer plant species, bees, butterflies and birds. Some of these have been vacant since the last war. Other areas have been lost over the last 10 years to building infill as Berlin tries to address the housing shortage in the city.

sections.title: Useful links
sections.content:
If you would like to find out more about wildlife, parks or exploring nature in Berlin why not visit the NABU website where you can learn about upcoming events they organise around the city. 

 

We would like to thank the following individuals who provided photographs to illustrate the map: Peter Foss
